Introduction

This article discusses systemic (hypothermia) and local (frostbite) cold injuries.

Hypothermia

Accidental (ie, environmental) hypothermia is caused by cold exposure.  Secondary causes of hypothermia (eg, myxedema, sepsis, adrenal insufficiency) are discussed in other articles.

Pathophysiology

Core body temperature is sensed by the anterior hypothalamus, which defends against hypothermia (ie, core body temperature <35 C [95 F]) through several mechanisms (

figure 1
).

  • Shivering
  • Nonshivering thermogenesis:  heat generated from brown adipose tissue (eg, mainly adjacent to the heart and great vessels).  Upregulation of the mitochondrial uncoupling protein (UCP1) dissipates the proton gradient as heat (ie, instead of ATP) (
    figure 2
    ).
  • Peripheral vasoconstriction:  blood shunted toward internal organs.
  • Behavioral thermoregulation (eg, keep moving, seek shelter).

These mechanisms can be overwhelmed during prolonged exposure to cold.  Severe hypothermia is most often found when one or more of the following clinical risk factors are present:

  • Rapid heat loss (eg, cold, damp clothing; drowning)
  • Impaired thermoregulation due to frailty/old age, drugs/toxins (eg, antipsychotics, beta blockers), neurologic conditions (eg, spinal cord injury), or conditions that impair peripheral vasoconstriction (eg, alcohol, nitrovasodilators, autonomic neuropathy)
  • Adverse social determinants (eg, severe psychiatric illness, substance use disorders, housing instability)

Staging and management

Manifestations and management of hypothermia (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
) track with core body temperature (eg, anal or esophageal thermometer).

Mild (32-35 C [90-95 F]): Thermoregulation is intact:

  • Manifestations:  shivering, cold pressor response (ie, vasoconstriction, hypertension), increased cardiac output (ie, sympathetic stimulation).
  • Management:  passive external rewarming (eg, removal of wet clothing; warm, dry blankets).

Moderate (28-32 C [82-90 F]): Thermoregulation begins to falter:

  • Manifestations:  progressive loss of shivering, confusion and lethargy, decreasing cardiac output (eg, bradycardia), decreased respiratory drive.
  • Management:  active external rewarming (eg, heated blankets, forced air warming).

Severe (<28 C [82 F]): Thermoregulation has failed:

  • Manifestations:  coma mimicking brain death (ie, apnea; fixed, dilated pupils), cardiovascular collapse, ECG with Osborn (J) waves and QT interval prolongation, ventricular arrhythmias (eg, ventricular fibrillation/ventricular tachycardia).
  • Management: 
    • Immediate priority:  emergency stabilization (eg, endotracheal intubation if obtunded, warmed [42 C {107.6 F}] IV fluid boluses for hypotension). 
    • Next:  active (core) internal rewarming (eg, endovascular catheter heating, warm peritoneal dialysis). 
    • Extracorporal membrane oxygenation may be needed for refractory hypothermia and/or shock.

Additional clinical findings, frequently seen in moderate to severe hypothermia, include the following:

  • Volume depletion (from cold-induced natriuresis) or cardiogenic pulmonary edema (from myocardial depression)
  • Electrolyte (eg, hypokalemia, hypophosphatemia) disturbances (from transcellular shifts) and metabolic acidosis (from mitochondrial dysfunction)
  • Coagulopathy (from decreased clotting factor activity, although PT/active PTT measurements may be normal), leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia (from splenic sequestration)

During early rewarming, core temperature can paradoxically drop due to peripheral vasodilation, returning cold blood into the central circulation.  In patients with difficulty rewarming, infection should be highly suspected (eg, hypothermic immunosuppression) and empiric antibiotics are often administered.

Frostbite

Pathophysiology

Frostbite is a complex injury involving several mechanisms, including freezing (intracellular ice crystal formation) and thawing, leading to cell rupture, ischemia, and ischemia-reperfusion injury (eg, reactive oxygen species, inflammatory cytokines during freeze-thaw cycles).  It typically occurs on distal or poorly insulated areas with relatively low blood flow (eg, fingers, toes, cheeks, ears).

Staging and management

Frostbite staging is based on the depth of tissue damage (similar to burn injury):

  • Frostnip:  no tissue damage (mildest cold injury, prefrostbite).  Symptoms include pain and dysesthesias (eg, numbness, tingling).  Transient pallor reverses quickly after rewarming.
  • Superficial frostbite:  epidermis (first degree) and dermis (second degree) involvement.  Skin is typically erythematous and may develop inflammatory blistering on rewarming.
  • Deep frostbite:  subcutaneous tissue (third degree) or muscle and bone (fourth degree) involvement.  Skin is purplish and cyanotic and is typically hardened.  The affected tissue is typically anesthetic, even after rewarming.  There is a high risk for permanent tissue loss (eg, gangrene, eschar, mummification).

Regardless of staging, management of frostbite injuries follows the same general pathway (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
):

  • Rewarming:  Rapid but controlled (ie, avoid burn) rewarming is associated with better tissue preservation.  The frostbitten area should be submerged in a warm bath slightly above body temperature (eg, 39 C [102.2 F]).  Rewarming several fingers typically takes 30-60 minutes.  The frostbitten site should never be allowed to refreeze because repeated thawing leads to greater tissue loss.
  • Thrombolysis (sometimes):  If rewarming fails to restore circulation (eg, digit is still cyanotic), perfusion should be assessed (eg, technetium 99m scan, angiography) to rule out intravascular thrombosis.  Thrombolytic therapy (eg, tissue plasminogen activator) with or without a vasodilator (eg, prostaglandin) is sometimes required.
  • Surgery (sometimes):  Debridement may be required for infection or ischemic tissue (ie, wet gangrene).  Patients typically have signs of superimposed cellulitis (eg, purulent blistering and drainage).  Deep frostbite can result in mummification, with eventual autoamputation or delayed surgical amputation.

Management also includes basic wound care (loose, dry wrapping; separating neighboring fingers) and aggressive analgesia because of potentially excruciating pain, especially in more superficial frostbites with intact sensory fibers.  Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (eg, ibuprofen preferred) can also inhibit vascular sludging and decrease inflammatory injury after thawing.

Related cold conditions

Nonfreezing cold injuries

  • Chilblains (pernio): painful, pruritic, inflammatory skin lesions (
    image 1
    ) (eg, erythematous patches, blistering in some cases) induced by cold exposure, mainly affecting the tips of fingers and toes.  The damage is very similar to epidermal (first-degree) frostbite, but there is no freezing involved (ie, chilblains occur at temperatures >0 C [32 F]).
  • Trench foot:  macerated skin and soft tissue due to prolonged immersion in cold and damp environments (eg, experiencing homelessness, wearing wet boots).  Repeated episodes of vascular sludging and sensory denervation can eventually lead to foot deformation.  In some cases, bacterial superinfection and gangrene can occur.

Cold-exacerbated phenomena

  • Raynaud phenomenon (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 3
    ):  Intense digital vasoconstriction is typically triggered by cold exposure.  Attacks characteristically transition from initial pallor (ie, white: initial vasoconstriction) to cyanosis (ie, blue: digital ischemia) to hyperemia (ie, red: reperfusion), mimicking frostbite followed by rewarming.  However, unlike frostbite, the pallor is sharply demarcated and there is no tissue necrosis (unless severe).  The phenomenon can be primary (ie, idiopathic) or secondary (eg, scleroderma).
  • Cryoglobulinemia (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 4
    ):  Vascular sludging (eg, hyperviscosity) or vasculitis (eg, complement fixation) is due to immune complexes that precipitate at cooler temperatures (eg, ear lobes, nose, fingers (
    figure 3
    ).  In contrast to frostbite, cryoglobulinemic vasculitis causes palpable purpura (vs cyanosis) and systemic organ involvement (eg, glomerulonephritis).
  • Cold agglutinins (
    ðŸ“Š View Table: table 5
    ):  Cold exposure can induce autoimmune hemolytic anemia in susceptible patients (eg, Mycoplasma infection).  Agglutination of red cells in distal capillaries (eg, fingers, ears) can produce transient cyanosis.

Summary

Hypothermia is typically seen in the setting of rapid heat loss (eg, drowning) and impaired thermogenesis (eg, old age).  Prolonged cold exposure causes defense mechanisms (eg, shivering) to fail, leading to severe hypothermia (eg, encephalopathy, arrhythmias, shock).  Management ranges from external rewarming (eg, heated blankets) for mild to moderate hypothermia (ie, 28-35 C [82-95 F]) and active internal rewarming (eg, warm IV fluids, endovascular heating catheter) for severe hypothermia (ie, <28 C [<82 F], hemodynamic instability).

Frostbite involves freezing and thawing, leading to cell rupture, ischemia, and reperfusion injury.  Superficial frostbite (ie, epidermis and dermis involvement) produces erythema, whereas deep frostbite (subcutaneous tissues) produces cyanosis.  Management includes rapid rewarming (eg, 39 C [102.2 F] water bath), analgesia, and local wound care.  Thrombolysis is sometimes required for limb salvage, and surgical debridement is reserved for late gangrene.
